# sample-irreverent-writing

persona: Hangman
tone: irreverent, sharp, witty, intelligent
content-type: essays, philosophizing, self-help, self-improvement
genre: irreverent self-help

## sample-irrev

It was the digital nomad dream and as a twenty-five-year-old
adventure-seeker, it was exactly what I wanted out of life.

Sure, I had some admirable
values going on—a thirst to see the world, a curiosity for people and
culture, some old-fashioned adventure-seeking.

But there also existed a
faint outline of shame underlying everything else.

At the time I was hardly
aware of it, but if I was completely honest with myself, I knew there was a
screwed-up value lurking there, somewhere beneath the surface.

By this time my
little dating advice blog was getting some traffic and I was actually making
a modest amount of money selling PDFs and courses online.

I planned on
spending much of the next few years living abroad, experiencing new
cultures, and taking advantage of the lower cost of living in a number of
developing countries in Asia and Latin Americ

It was the digital nomad dream and as a twenty-five-year-old
adventure-seeker, it was exactly what I wanted out of life.

But as sexy and heroic as my plan sounded, not all of the values driving
me to this nomadic lifestyle were healthy ones.

Sure, I had some admirable
values going on—a thirst to see the world, a curiosity for people and
culture, some old-fashioned adventure-seeking.

I had spent the past few years overcompensating for the inadequacy
and social anxiety of my teenager years, and as a result I felt like I could
meet anybody I wanted, be friends with anybody I wanted,

And I like it
that way.

You
don’t smile at strangers or pretend to like anything you don’t.

If you really like someone and are having a
great time, you tell her that you like her and are having a great time.

There was nothing combative about the way she said
it; it was spoken as if it were some mundane fact—like the quality of the
weather that day, or her shoe size—but I was still shocked.

This is a cornerstone of many of the
so-called positive thinking books: open yourself up to opportunities, be
accepting, say yes to everything and everyone, and so on.

That rejection is an inherent and necessary part of maintaining our
values, and therefore our identity.

The desire to avoid rejection at all costs, to avoid confrontation and
conflict, the desire to attempt to accept everything equally and to make

everything cohere and harmonize, is a deep and subtle f
Rejection is an important and crucial life skill.
Honesty is a natural human craving.

metadata.ai_analysis:
1. Tone Characteristics: The tone of this writing sample is predominantly irreverent, with a sharp and witty edge. It's also intellectual, as the author uses complex ideas and concepts to express his thoughts. The tone is also somewhat introspective, as the author reflects on his past experiences and values.

2. Unique Voice Signatures: The author's voice is characterized by a candid, no-nonsense style. He doesn't shy away from discussing personal flaws and mistakes, which adds a layer of authenticity to his writing. He also uses a conversational style, with phrases like "But there also existed a faint outline of shame underlying everything else" and "It was a strange life, replete with fantastic, horizon-breaching experiences as well as superficial highs designed to numb my underlying pain." This creates a sense of intimacy and familiarity with the reader.

3. Emotional Range and Expression Patterns: The author's emotional range is quite broad, covering everything from excitement and adventure to shame and regret. He expresses these emotions in a direct, unfiltered way, often using vivid and evocative language. For example, he describes his past lifestyle as a "game of global hopscotch" and his current life as "a house and furniture and an electric bill and a wife."

4. Humor Style and Techniques: The author's humor is dry and self-deprecating. He often uses humor to highlight the absurdity of his past behavior, such as when he describes his past self as having a "grandiose sense of connectivity to the world" and bouncing "back and forth across countries and oceans."

5. Rhetorical Devices Commonly Used: The author frequently uses metaphors and similes to illustrate his points. For example, he compares his past lifestyle to a game of hopscotch and his current life to a house with furniture and an electric bill. He also uses repetition for emphasis, such as when he repeats the phrase "anybody I wanted" to highlight his past sense of entitlement. Additionally, he uses rhetorical questions to provoke thought and engage the reader, such as "If I could experience everything equally, then I should experience them all equally, right?"
